explanation: The third law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a perfect crystal approaches zero as temperature approaches absolute zero. This law provides an absolute reference point for entropy calculations and explains why absolute zero is unattainable. It has profound implications for low-temperature physics and quantum statistical mechanics.

definitions.definition: Entropy as a function of temperature.
Residual entropy at absolute zero (typically zero for perfect crystals).
Any extensive thermodynamic variable (volume, pressure, etc.).

assumptions: The system is a perfect crystal with no structural defects or disorder.
All nuclear spins are aligned (no nuclear entropy contribution).
The system has a unique ground state (single microstate at T = 0).
Quantum statistical mechanics applies at low temperatures.

derivation.description: Start with the Boltzmann definition of entropy in terms of microstates.
At absolute zero, a perfect crystal has only one accessible microstate (the ground state).
Therefore, entropy approaches zero as temperature approaches zero.
Any partial derivative of entropy involves the logarithmic derivative of microstates.
derivation.equation: partial S/partial X = k_B (partial ln Omega/partial X)

derivation.description: Since Ω = 1 at T = 0, all entropy derivatives also approach zero.
